_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the Thackerville Terminal facility:



NGL Supply Terminal Company is committed to the safety of its workers, the public, and the environment. Its accidental release policy is an integrated approach, involving employee participation, management practices, written procedures, and training. NGL has developed a comprehensive Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) accident prevention program considering all aspects of process operation and maintenance. The accident prevention program includes compliance with ongoing mechanical integrity inspections, which includes the API RP 510 Pressure Vessel Inspection Program and API RP 570 Piping Inspection Program. In addition, the facility conducts 3 year PSM compliance audits. If an emergency were to occur, it is NGL's policy to notify the Thackerville Volunteer Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. The Thackerville Terminal also maintains incipient stage fire fighting equipment on site. Additionally, this facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LPG storage, and it is NGL's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. 



A description of the Thackerville Terminal facility and the regulated substances handled:



This facility is a bulk terminal storing LPG for resale to retail propane dealers. The facility consists of two (2) 90,000 gallon storage tanks holding approximately 330,000 pounds each of liquid propane.  There is also the capacity for eight (8) 33,000- gallon rail cars onsite and three (3) 14,500 gallon trucks.  There are both manual and automatic emergency shutdown systems on all LPG equipment at the site.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:



This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The LPG system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordan

ce with NFPA-58 and state law.



Five-year accident history:



NGL Supply Terminal Company acquired the facility on December 1, 2013. There has not been an accident involving LPG that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or any shelter in place.



The emergency response program:



NGL Supply Terminal Company has developed an emergency action plan specific to this facility. In the event of an emergency involving the Thackerville Terminal's LPG system, it is NGL's policy to notify the Thackerville Volunteer Fire Department and request that they help in responding to the emergency. NGL has trained employees in incipient stage fire fighting. The Thackerville Terminal has coordinated the facility's response plans with the LEPC and fire department; members of the LEPC and fire department have been provided the opportunity to visit the Thackerville Terminal facility and inspect the LPG storage system.



Planned changes to improve safety:



NGL Supply Terminal Company, LLC will continually strive for safety improvement. Periodic process safety inspections and Process Hazard Analyses will be conducted followed with timely response.
